tutorials.name: Basics #1: Getting started!
tutorials.description: Learn the basics: from viewing a project, forking it and a understanding basic concepts of MLReef.
tutorials.epilogue:
## Congratulations!!
You have finished your first tutorial. You should now be able to:

- Explore and fork public projects
- Explore the data in your repository
- Create a new experiment

tasks.title: Your first tutorial!
tasks.instructions: This is the tutorial helper. It will guide you in your journey, step by step. A small tip, you can click on these images here to expand them.

tasks.title: This is your dashboard
tasks.instructions: Here, you can see your project repositories and explore public ones from the community.

tasks.title: Two types of project repositories
tasks.instructions: In **ML Projects** you will do all the data and ML related work. The other class are to host code functions, such as **models** or **data visualizations**.

tasks.title: Now, go to the "Basic tutorials" ML project
tasks.instructions: Click this [link](/mlreef_1/basic-tutorials) or type **Basic Tutorial** in the search field under the **ML Projects** tab.

tasks.title: Fork the project
tasks.instructions: Click the forking button. This will copy the entire project to your namespace.

tasks.title: Wait until fork is completed
tasks.instructions: In general, the forking might take some time, please be patient!

tasks.title: The repository is now yours!
tasks.instructions:
##### Congratulations! 
Feel free to navigate around the repository. We will continue with an experiment in the next step.

tasks.title: Creating a cats and dogs classifier
tasks.instructions: The objective is to train a neural network that will be able to distinguish between cats and dogs. Easy!

tasks.title: Open the "Experiments" tab
tasks.instructions: Click the experiment tab. In this section you can train your models with cats and dogs images.

tasks.title: Create a new experiment
tasks.instructions: An experiment is a model training. It is called an experiment, because with neural networks you donÂ´t know the exact outcome before you tried.

tasks.title: Choose your training data
tasks.instructions: Click the select data button and then choose the **Cats_Dogs_Tutorial** folder. This step will store the path to your dataset for all models (and other operations) you choose.

tasks.title: Choose the "Basic Tutorial Model" model
tasks.instructions: Now, search and *drag and drop* the model named **Basic Tutorial Model** to your experiment pipeline.

tasks.title: Enter basic parameters
tasks.instructions: The data-input path should already contain the path as selected before. In the output field enter **output** - your model artifacts will be stored here. Fill in others as we did or experiment with different params.

tasks.title: Start the experiment
tasks.instructions: If you successfully draged your model and filled all parameters, you should be able to execute your first experiment. Click **execute**.

tasks.title: Choose machine and execute
tasks.instructions: Choose the **GPU machine** from the dropdown and execute your experiment. Your model is now being trained. Press the **show results** button to continue.

tasks.title: Discover your experiment
tasks.instructions: You now should be able to see your new running experiment (if not, refresh this page!) with all metrics, version of data and code used. A graph will show up soon with more details.

tasks.title: Go more in depth!
tasks.instructions: Click on the experiment name to enter a detailed view with more insights and to download the generated model artifacts.

tasks.title: Navigate the tabs
tasks.instructions: Explore the different tabs and finally navigate to the **files** tab. As soon as the experiment has finished, you can download the model and use it!

tutorials.name: Basic #2: Data processing
tutorials.description: Process data and create new datasets for iterative model training.

tasks.title: Navigate to the **Data** tab
tasks.instructions: Open your **Basic Tutorials** ML project and navigate to the data tab.

tasks.title: Go to Data Ops pipeline
tasks.instructions: Open the **Data Ops** pipeline. Here you can pre-process and create new datasets based on your existing files in your repository.

tasks.title: Select data to process
tasks.instructions: Click the select data button and then choose the **Cats_Dogs_Tutorial** folder by selecting it. The scripts we will use will process all files contained in the path while maintaining the folder structure.

tasks.title: Choose - Add noise - operation.
tasks.instructions: In the Data Ops list, search the data processing operation named **add noise** and drag it into your pipeline. This will add speckles to all images.

tasks.title: Enter basic parameters
tasks.instructions: The data-input path should already contain the path to your images. Fill in the output path and choose any mode you want. You can hover over the question mark to get more help.

tasks.title: Start the data processing
tasks.instructions: You now should be able to execute your Data Ops pipeline to create a new dataset. This will create a new entry in **Datasets** and also create a new branch with the output data. Click **execute**.

tasks.title: Choose machine and execute
tasks.instructions: Choose the **GPU machine** from the dropdown and execute the pipeline. Your pipeline should start and cerate a new dataset.

tasks.title: Return to pipeline view
tasks.instructions: Instead of moving forward, letÂ´s create a more complex pipeline. Return to the **Data Ops* pipeline view.

steps.name: Create a more complex processing pipeline

tasks.title: Select data to pre-process.
tasks.instructions: If needed, click the select data button and then choose the data folder as before.

tasks.title: Remove Add noise operation.
tasks.instructions: We will start with another data operation. Remove the **add noise** operation from the pipeline.

tasks.title: Choose Augment operation.
tasks.instructions: The augment operation duplicates and changes your existing data. This is an easy way to create new and more data from existing data!

tasks.title: Enter augment parameters
tasks.instructions:
Enter the following parameters: 
+ **output-path**: out1 
+ **iterations**: 3 
+ **rotation-range**: 0 
+ **width-shift-range**: 0 
+ **height-shift-range**: 0 
+ **shear-range**: 0.1 
+ **zoom-range**: 0.2 
+ **horizontal-flip**: true 
+ **vertical-flip**: false.

tasks.title: Choose Random Crop operation.
tasks.instructions: The next concatenated data opeartion will crop a part of the input images. Drag the operation in position 2 into the pipeline, right after the **Augment** operation.

tasks.title: Enter random crop parameters
tasks.instructions:
This time, we will use the output generated from the augment opeartion as input for the next. Enter the following parameters: Type in the **input-path**: out1 (or the output-path name you entered in the augment operation). 
Enter in **output-path** a different folder name (e.g. out2). 
Define the resultion of the croped images (e.g. 100px) for both height and width and enter a random seed value.

tasks.title: Start the data processing
tasks.instructions:
Now, let's create this more complex data processing pipeline. 
Info: You can create any number of concatenations and chaining logics using the input and output paths!

tasks.title: Choose machine and execute
tasks.instructions: Choose the **GPU machine** from the dropdown and execute the pipeline. Your pipeline should start and create a new dataset. Press the **show results** button to continue.

tasks.title: Go to experiment section
tasks.instructions: Click the experiment tab.

tasks.title: Create a new experiment.
tasks.instructions: Click the new experiment button, which is now located at the top right.

tasks.title: Select new dataset
tasks.instructions:
Click the select data button and then select the newly created datset from the dropdown button. 
Info: all datasets are also stored as branches in your repository.

tasks.title: Review the dataset status
tasks.instructions: In the dropdown, you can see the status of the pipelines (green = done, orange = running, red = stopped).

tasks.title: Select new pre-processed files
tasks.instructions: You should be able to see now your newly created output folder (i.e. out 1 and out 2). Select out 2, which contains all newly created images from before.

tasks.title: Finalize with a new model training
tasks.instructions: **Congratulations!** This is how you create and iterate using data pre-precessing. If you want, finish this tutorial with a new experiment!
